question.text: Which sounds more natural: A or B?
option: To book in advance is important.
It is important to book in advance.
question.answer: It is important to book in advance.

exercise.rubric: Choose the right option for each sentence.

question.text: It’s worth #singletouch to Wales if you have the time.
It’s no use #singletouch to explain – I’m not interested.
It surprised me your not #singletouch my name.

exercise.rubric: Are these exclamations correct: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: Here comes Freddy!
Here Freddy comes!
Here comes she!
Here she comes!
Off go we!
Off we go!

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences correct: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: ‘What do you mean?’ <item>asked Henry.</item>
‘What do you mean?’ <item>Henry asked.</item>
‘What do you mean?’ <item>he asked.</item>
‘What do you mean?’ <item>asked he.</item>
Look at this sentence. Which of the questions below it does it answer?
question.input_text: ‘It was Daniel that my aunt took to London yesterday, not Lucy.’
option: ‘Did your aunt take Lucy to London yesterday?’
‘Did Lucy take your aunt to London yesterday?’
question.answer: ‘Did your aunt take Lucy to London yesterday?’

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: <item>Who</item> influenced me most as a child was my grandfather.
<item>The person who</item> influenced me most as a child was my grandfather.

exercise.rubric: Fill in the two missing words in each sentence.

question.text: The #gap we always met was the café in the park.
The #gap we always met was Tuesday.
The #gap we met was to play chess.

exercise.rubric: Can options A–C begin the sentence: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.input_text: ... I remember was a terrible pain in my head.
question.text: All ...
The first thing ...
The only thing ...

exercise.rubric: Can expressions A–D end the sentence correctly: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: ... and I.
... and so do I.
... and so do I love dancing.
... and I do too.
Which sentence sounds more natural: A or B?
option: How many unhappy marriages there are is very surprising.
It is very surprising how many unhappy marriages there are.
question.answer: It is very surprising how many unhappy marriages there are.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: It <item>looks if</item> we’re going to have trouble with Anna again.
<item>It looks as if</item> we’re going to have trouble with Anna again.
<item>It looks as though</item> we’re going to have trouble with Anna again.
<item>It will be a pity if</item> we have to ask her to leave.

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences possible in a formal written style: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: She was very religious, <item>as were</item> most of her friends.
I felt very nervous, <item>but were not worried</item> my friends.
So ridiculous <item>did she look</item> that everybody burst out laughing.

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: We cannot park here under any circumstances.
Under no circumstances we can park here.
Under no circumstances can we park here.
Which of these is more likely to be used in a children’s story?
option: A great castle stood in front of the children.
In front of the children stood a great castle.
question.answer: In front of the children stood a great castle.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W) when telling a story?

question.text: I stopped the car and <item>up walked a police officer</item>.
The door opened and <item>out came Angela’s boyfriend</item>.

exercise.rubric: Look at this sentence. Are the sentences below it possible ways of emphasising the same idea: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.input_text: Jake isn’t the chairman; he’s the secretary.
question.text: The secretary is what Jake is.
What Jake is is the secretary.
Look at this sentence. Which is the most normal reply?
question.input_text: ‘I thought you’d decided not to come to the party!’
option: ‘No. <item>What it was</item> was that the car broke down.’
‘No. <item>What happened</item> was that the car broke down.’
‘No. <item>It</item> was that the car broke down.’
question.answer: ‘No. What happened was that the car broke down.’

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: I have always paid my bills and I always <item>will pay them</item>.
I have always paid my bills and I always <item>will</item>.

exercise.rubric: Which words can you leave out in informal spoken English?

sample.text: <item>The</item> car’s running badly. <item>It</item> doesn’t like cold weather.
answer: Car's running badly. Doesn’t like cold weather.

question.text: There’s nobody at home – my wife’s in Scotland.

right: Nobody at home – wife's in Scotland.
Nobody at home - wife’s in Scotland.
Nobody at home – wife in Scotland.

question.text: You’re keeping well, I hope. Have you seen Joe?

answer.right: Keeping well, I hope. Seen Joe?

question.text: ‘Did you enjoy the film?’ ‘I couldn’t understand a word of it.’

right: 'Enjoy the film?' 'Couldn't understand a word (of it).'
'Enjoy the film?' 'Couldn't understand a word of it.'
'Enjoy the film?' 'Couldn’t understand a word of it.'
‘Enjoy the film?’ ‘Couldn't understand a word of it.’
‘Enjoy the film?’ ‘Couldn’t understand a word of it.’
Enjoy the film? Couldn't understand a word of it.
Enjoy the film? Couldn't understand a word.
Enjoy the film? Couldn’t understand a word of it.
Enjoy the film? Couldn’t understand a word.

question.text: Be careful what you say – there are children listening.

answer.right: Careful what you say – children listening.

exercise.rubric: Are these replies possible in informal spoken English: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.input_text: ‘When are you coming to see us?’
question.text: ‘<item>I’m coming</item> to see you tomorrow, I hope.’
‘<item>Am coming</item> to see you tomorrow, I hope.’
‘<item>Coming</item> to see you tomorrow, I hope.’

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: ‘Get up!’ ‘<item>I am</item>.’
<item>If you can</item>, send me a postcard when you arrive.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: She made <item>that she disagreed clear</item>.
She made <item>clear that she disagreed</item>.
She made <item>it clear that she disagreed</item>.

exercise.rubric: Put in it or nothing (-) to make correct sentences.

question.text: We found #singletouch tiring to listen to him.
I cannot bear #singletouch to see people crying.
We love #singletouch when you sing.
I take #singletouch that you won’t be working tomorrow.
I found #singletouch strange being in her house.
We would appreciate #singletouch if you would keep us informed.
We owe #singletouch to society to help those who need help.
I’ll leave #singletouch to you to inform the other members.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: I wondered <item>how reliable was the information</item> I had been given.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: Not far from here <item>can you see</item> foxes.
Not only <item>did we lose</item> our money, we also wasted our time.
Under no circumstances <item>will I agree</item> to your conditions.

exercise.rubric: Are these inversions correct (in formal literary writing): yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: Seldom <item>had I been</item> in such danger before.
Sometimes <item>had I felt</item> frightened in the past.
Only then <item>did I understand</item> how bad the situation was.
Little <item>did I know</item> that I would soon be saved.
Never <item>have I been</item> so glad to see someone arrive.
Not for a moment <item>did she realise</item> the danger she was in.
Not until he received her email <item>did he fully understand</item> her feelings for him.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: Much as I respect your judgement, I think you’re completely mistaken.

exercise.rubric: Change the emphasis by reconstructing the sentence with different endings as shown.

question.input_text: What Emily kept in the bath was a goldfish.
question.text: #gap was Emily.
answer: The person who kept a goldfish in the bath

question.text: #gap was the bath.
answer: The place where Emily kept a goldfish
(The place) where Emily kept a goldfish

question.text: #gap was to keep a goldfish in the bath.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: <item>Why I’m here is</item> to talk about my plans.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: What he did was <item>scream</item>.
What he did was <item>to scream</item>.
What he did was, <item>he screamed</item>.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: <item>This</item> is where you pay.
<item>Here</item> is where you pay.

exercise.rubric: Formal (F), normal (N) or informal (I)?

question.text: It is I who am responsible.
It’s me that’s responsible.

feedback.desc:
273.2
A is very formal. B is very informal.

exercise.rubric: Are these replies right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: ‘I suppose I <item>could</item>.’
‘I suppose I <item>could have</item>.’
‘I suppose I <item>could have been</item>.’

exercise.rubric: Are these replies right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: ‘He <item>might</item>.’
‘He <item>might do</item>.’

feedback.desc:
279.6
B is not right in American English.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: ‘Are you and Gillian getting married?’ ‘<item>We hope</item>.’
‘Are you and Gillian getting married?’ ‘<item>We hope to</item>.’
There’s more snow these days than there <item>used to</item>.
‘Do you want to go to University?’ ‘<item>I’d like</item>.’
Stay as long as <item>you like</item>.
